section.title: Introduction
section.para: perfSONAR is an infrastructure for network performance monitoring and data exchange. It consists of a set of services delivering performance measurements in a federated environment. These services act as an intermediate layer, between the performance measurement tools and the diagnostic or visualization applications.

This framework is designed in the service-oriented style, implying that a set of elementary functions has been isolated and can be provided by different software entities. In this model, all services must communicate using well-defined protocols. This document describes the base communication protocol to be used by all services and clients in the perfSONAR framework. These communication protocols are based on and utilize the same XML structure used to exchange and store measurement data as defined by the NM-WG in the OGF.

This document will proceed as follows: we first examine why this document is necessary and what it will achieve. We follow with a discussion of the syntactic details and a semantic description of the major message types. After, we introduce two common protocols used by every service in the perfSONAR infrastructure: the Echo and Authentication protocols. Finally we conclude with some description of other protocol documents.

section.title: Motivation
section.para: A common message exchange pattern in perfSONAR is a Request followed by a Response. As this pattern is important, we will show a basic interaction and build on it. Consider this example of a client application interacting with some perfSONAR service in search of data.

It becomes the burden of both the service developer and the client developer to document what an exchange consists of, and how it takes place (albeit from different points of view). A second example involving different actors is quite similar:

Essentially, the acts of sending messages, receiving responses, and being able to discern success or failure are common across many specific interactions. One aim of this document is to prevent the following redundancies:

listitem.para: Duplicate Schemata - Messages will differ from service to service, but the overarching concepts will not; we present some of the common features that must be present in every exchange and describe how extension is possible.
Duplicate Error Conditions - Some errors will occur across services and do not need to be defined repeatedly (e.g. Unknown Message Type).

Duplication of Common Exchanges - Every service in perfSONAR is capable of receiving and acting upon common protocols such as Echo and AA. These will be presented as the first two extensions to this base.

section.para: With this base, it will be possible to define protocol extensions on a type-by-type basis instead of service by service. This also allows for a sufficient reduction in documentation due to service types implementing the same underlying format of messages (e.g. Measurement Archives mostly implement the same message types with notable exceptions and data differences).

section.title: Messages
section.para: Services in perfSONAR rely on a simple communication protocol based on the notion of Request and Response messages. Both messages are fundamentally the same: a series of metadata and data units linked via identifying attributes. These concepts, taken from the NM-WG format, observe the same rules with regards to splitting both measurement and communication into logical units.

section.title: Preliminary Example
section.para: To cement an early understanding of how the messages work, consider this rudimentary query for some data from a service:
section.programlisting:
<message type="request">
<metadata id="m1"> <!-- some partial metadata the service may or may not understand --> </metadata>
<data id="d1" metadatIdRef="m1" />
</message>
section.para: There are some important things to note about this query:

listitem.para: Message Type - Every message in perfSONAR contains a type, these are necessary to be able to identify the semantic intentions of the internal data
Message Structure - There may be many metadata and data elements in each message, and there does not need to be a matching data for every metadata (e.g. chaining)
Metadata - Can contain measurement data, or perhaps identifying information about a service, note that we still loosely observe the static rule of thumb

Data - Serves a dual role: in request messages this may be empty (e.g. this is a data trigger, it lets the service know we need action on the accompanying metadata), or it can contain dynamic measurement data or even other metadata elements

section.para: Simply stated, we are sending some type of request that is interested in getting back some data that matches the sent metadata. This metadata may be partial or complete. When the service receives this request it will check for several things:

listitem.para: Syntax - Does the XML parse
Message Type - Can this service accept and act on this kind of message
Structure - Is there at least a single metadata and data pair that is capable of being acted on; do any chains resolve properly
Semantics - Does the request make sense, can the metadata be acted upon

section.para: The service has two options at this point: acting on the message and returning data or reporting some other form of status. We will explore the first option initially:
section.programlisting:
<message type="response">
<metadata id="m1"> <!-- specific metadata that matched --> </metadata>
<data id="d1" metadatIdRef="m1"> <!-- lots and lots of data --> </data>
</message>
section.para: Note this message is similar to the response in many ways. The major differences:

listitem.para: Message Type - This becomes the foil of the previous request; it is common to simply replace the word Request with Response
Message Structure - All valid metadata and data pairings will be acted on, chained items may be truncated
Metadata - May be completed if it was not this way in the request
Data - Should contain information, especially if it was empty in the initial request

section.para: The second situation is not very different, but is indicative of something occurring that was not expected. We don't explicitly use the term error to describe this situation because many paths that lead to this are not wrong. Some examples of status may be:

listitem.para: Message Syntax/Structure/Semantics - The service must be able to understand the request, if it cannot be parsed on either the syntactic or semantic levels the status should reflect this

Metadata/Data Search - The backend storage can simply be devoid of references to what a request is interested in, this can be expressed by returning nothing in the response or having an explicit message to do so
Catastrophic Events - Internal events may trigger some sort of panic in the service; note that not all events may be recovered from and are not the fault of the service itself

section.para: The general format of a status message is as follows, parallels between the previous response as well as the request can easily be drawn.
section.programlisting:
<message type="response">
<metadata id="m1"> <!-- some error code --> </metadata>
<data id="d1" metadatIdRef="m1"> <!-- some human readable information --> </data>
</message>

section.title: Message Actions
section.para: The example from characterizes many of the common actions services perform on receipt of a request message. A more formal description of this interaction is described below. Note that this is a generalized attempt, and does not directly reflect the actions of any particular service. Protocol extensions must provide a description where this example is lacking.

The example illustrates that any stage of processing a request may trigger entry into the status routine. Specifics regarding available status messages should be categorized by service type and will appear in the protocol extensions; specifics based on a particular action a service may take based on internal conditions will appear in the service documentation.

section.title: Request Message
section.para: The request message is a container for submitting various forms of communication to perfSONAR capable services. Enclosed in this simple envelope will be a series of metadata and data pairs containing various instructions to act on. We first present a very simple schema in along with an analysis of the elements in . We conclude with examples in .

section.title: Request Message Schema
section.para: The following schema is a native description of the request schema as in the RELAX-NG language. Through the use of tools such as Trang and MSV it is possible to convert this to other widely accepted formats such as XSD.

section.title: Request Message Analysis
section.para: The following is a breakdown of the elements featured in the schema. Note that services in general must not implement or attempt to understand this, it is provided as a tool to aid in the development of extensions.

section.title: Message
section.para: The message element serves as a container for transporting requests to perfSONAR capable services. The message itself is unremarkable, it features attributes to aid in the identification of messages and contains elements with legitimate content. We first examine the available attributes:

listitem.para: id - Identifier that can be used to track state between messages and services
type - Designates the message to a particular type; fully enumerated in each protocol extension

section.para: There are three major elements that may be contained in the message element:

listitem.para: Parameters - Described in
Metadata - Described in
Data - Described in

section.title: Parameters
section.para: The parameters element encloses a series of parameter elements that can be used to adjust variable aspects of a request message. This element serves merely as a container for the elements that will populate it. The single available attribute is described first:

listitem.para: id - Identifying attribute that can be used to track state.

section.para: There is only one available element, although it can be used multiple times.

listitem.para: Parameter - Described in

section.title: Parameter
section.para: The parameter element features a generic structure that allows it to easily adapt to the needs of a particular schema. Possible names and values will not be enumerated here, but will be done both at the protocol extension and service level.

listitem.para: name - Generically specify the name of some variable value
value - Can be used instead a text element to set the value of the name

section.para: In lieu of the value attribute, a text element may be used for the same purpose. This is the only element that is allowed for this instantiation of the parameters element.

section.title: Metadata
section.para: The metadata element normally contains the static parts of measurements, and will no doubt differ from service to service. Besides measurement data it is possible to send other items such as service descriptions. We leave the description of what is possible inside of a metadata blank, and use vague schema language that allows for any reasonable XML to be contained within.

There are two attributes possible. These are used to both track state and perform the various forms of chaining (e.g. operator or merge) that may be required in a request message. A detailed description follows:

listitem.para: id - Identifying attribute that can be used to track state.
metadataIdRef - Identifying attribute that can be used to track state or be linked to chaining.

section.title: Data
section.para: The data element normally contains the dynamic parts of measurements, and will no doubt differ from service to service. Besides collected measurements the data field may also be populated with query data, or even other other metadata information in certain applications. We leave the description of what is possible inside of a data blank, and use vague schema language that allows for any reasonable XML to be contained within.
There are two attributes possible. These are used to both track state inside of a request message. A detailed description follows:

listitem.para: id - Identifying attribute that can be used to track state.
metadataIdRef - used to link data to metadata.

section.title: Request Message Example
section.para: The following examples demonstrate some of the possible uses and layouts of request messages in the base protocol. These examples are not an attempt to be exhaustive, but rather some examples of ways to perform common tasks. Note that these messages are NOT indicative of a particular service.
The first example demonstrates the most common use case: a single metadata and data pair. This message represents the layouts of most request messages in the perfSONAR framework.
The second example is similar, but incorporates a parameters block that may be populated with optional behaviors for a service.

The third example is also similar to the first, but shows it is possible to ask for multiple pairs of metadata and data in a single message. Note that there are two empty data triggers to signify that each message be acted upon.

This example features merge chaining. Note there is only one data trigger, and it is at the tail of the chain. A service would perform the necessary chaining first, then act on the result of this operation.
The final example is an invalid case where the metadata does not have an appropriate data trigger.

section.title: Result Codes
section.para: There are currently two hierarchical systems in use to return status information about services. Each of these approaches takes into account the facts that there are many diverse services as well as different status messages that may be returned, but the newer of the approaches also allows for versioning and backwards compatibility that the original attempt did not consider. The original system must continue to be supported by all services for the foreseeable future, while a slow phase in of the latest eventTypes is attempted.

The original system, currently used by all perfSONAR services and explained in Result Codes, relies on a static tree of status information that is branched first by general features (i.e. success, error) and later by more specific characteristics such as service and error type. This hierarchy is however missing the ability to offer versions of different codes that would have the ability to become forward or backwards compatible and is not in the well known URI format used by other eventTypes.
section.programlisting: success. ls. something something_else ma. something error. ls. something ma. something something_else
section.para: The most recent description of this status paradigm follows the URI syntax already in use by other eventTypes and does allow version numbers to be assigned to the various messages. This will allow services to pick and choose which versions they may support more readily.
section.programlisting: http://schemas.perfsonar.net/status/ success/ ls/ something/ 1.0 something_else/ 1.0 1.1 ma/ something/ 1.0 error/ ma/ something/ 1.0 1.1 something_else/ 1.0

section.title: Extension
section.para: This document must become the basis for all extension protocols in the perfSONAR framework. As a demonstration we include two protocols that should be implemented by all perfSONAR services: and . These protocols will incorporate the preceding work to eliminate duplication as much as possible, only specifying parts that are necessary for clarification. Each extension may be treated as a separate work, and will include the necessary schema, analysis, and example sections.

section.title: Echo Protocol
section.para: The sole purpose of certain perfSONAR services is to aid in the discovery and protection of the enterprise. The tasks undertaken by these critical components also require sound communication protocols based on the same XML formats used to exchange and store measurement data as defined by the NM-WG in the OGF.

The Echo Protocol is currently used by client applications as well as other services to ascertain the liveness of a given perfSONAR service instance. A well formatted EchoRequest message, when sent to any perfSONAR service, should trigger a similar EchoResponse. This interaction allows a client or service to gauge the responsiveness of a service; the potential to learn more information is also available for services who wish to provide it.

The core functionality of the Echo Protocol is to provide a simple request and response message set capable of delivering rudimentary status information. This protocol for exchange is similar to other types of communication, notably . While this protocol may seem to be a reinvention of existing tooling, the extension possibility far outweighs the duplication of functionality.

We present an overview of the messages used in this protocol, including both schematic designs and examples for the and . We conclude with a brief description of where extensions are possible followed by some current examples in .

The remainder of this section will explain the origins of this command protocol in , detailed descriptions regarding syntax and semantics in and , an overview of status in , and finally points of extension will be discussed in .

section.title: Architecture
section.para: To ensure availability, each perfSONAR service must be able to respond to simple queries regarding status. Services that fail to answer a direct question may be experiencing difficulty, and therefore may not be able to complete interaction with interested parties. Client applications, services, or external monitoring tools (such as SmokePing) can use this simple method to quickly come to conclusions regarding framework availability.

All perfSONAR services must contain the ability to respond to the most basic of Echo Protocol messages as described by this document. The minimum requirement of an Echo Protocol exchange is simply responding to a properly encoded request. Echo Protocol extensions may be built from this general protocol to elicit additional functionality on a service by service basis to do tasks such as test the capabilities of the service, receive statistics, or monitor erroneous behavior. The assignment of these other tasks within an EchoRequest message is valid provided that the basic structure is not compromised.

section.title: Request Message
section.para: The EchoRequest message can be initiated by a client application or service wanting to know the availability of some other service. The format of this message is minimal with respect to other protocol messages as the input is rather simple.

All protocols used within perfSONAR are based on recommendations from the OGF's NM-WG, and have been initially described in Zurawski06Scalable. The basic format described in this work for measurements has been adapted as a template for use in service communication as well, keeping the concept of and intact.

The syntax is similar to that of a regular language, and allows for a rather compact description. The following describes the EchoRequest schema. section.title: Response Message
section.para: The EchoResponse message is a reply to a given EchoRequest message from a client application or service. Like the EchoRequest the format is kept very simple, exposing only a selection of the NM-WG work with respect to other perfSONAR services. This simplicity does however allow for limited extension, as discussed in . As discussed in , this response message is also based on recommendations from the NM-WG.

section.title: Protocol Extension
section.para: There are two avenues for extension within the Echo Protocol as described in this document. It is possible to manipulate the values contained within the eventType to advance functionality, or through schema modification it is possible to add additional elements capable of handling a wider range of actions. Extensions that modify the schema for a given service should be careful to not change the themes presented in this protocol specification. It is imperative that all services respect the basic functionality in their quest to add new features.

section.title: eventType Extension
section.para: The current accepted eventType for the Echo Protocol's EchoRequest message is http://schemas.perfsonar.net/tools/admin/echo/2.0. This action must be accepted by all services. By adding additional eventTypes with the same format it is possible to extract additional information via a service.

Consider simple service X. The designer of this service wishes to create a special behaviour for specific eventTypes. The following new eventTypes are added to his service code (and to his implementation of the schema):

listitem.para: http://schemas.perfsonar.net/tools/admin/echo/X/2.0 - Allows service contact information to be returned via nmwgr:datum
http://schemas.perfsonar.net/tools/admin/echo/X/contact/2.0 - Allows service contact information to be returned via nmwgr:datum
http://schemas.perfsonar.net/tools/admin/echo/X/stats/2.0 - Allows service usage statistics to be returned via nmwgr:datum
http://schemas.perfsonar.net/tools/admin/echo/X/db/2.0 - Allows a basic database test to be performed, the results of which are returned via nmwgr:datum

section.para: By simply allow some additional string matching to occur in the eventType it is now possible to receive additional data to check the health of the system.
